Problem:
Consider a complex function given by \( z(t) = u(t) + iv(t) \) where \( u(t) \) and \( v(t) \) are real functions of time \( t \), obeying the differential equations \( \dot{u} = Au \) and \( \dot{v} = Bv \), respectively, with constant matrices A and B. We explore the effect of an integral transformation \( \mathcal{T}(z) = \int_0^t e^{-\lambda s} z(s) \, ds \) on this complex function over time.

If \( \mathcal{T}(z) \) is applied to the function \( z(t) \) and then allowed to evolve under the differential equations without further intervention, will the transformed function \( \mathcal{T}(z)(T) \) at time T be the same as if \( z(t) \) was directly integrated to T under the differential equations?
Explanation: The transformation \( \mathcal{T}(z) \) changes the nature of the function by incorporating an exponential decay factor which impacts both \( u \) and \( v \), modifying their evolution paths. Integrating \( z(t) \) directly under the differential equations without the transformation would not include this decay, leading to different outcomes at time T.
